conclusion: To find the magnitude of the induced electromotive force (EMF) in the rectangular coil, we will use Faraday's Law of Electromagnetic Induction.
The formula for the induced EMF in a rotating coil in a uniform magnetic field is given by: \( \mathcal{E} = n \cdot B \cdot A \cdot \omega \cdot \sin(\omega t) \).
Where: - \( n \) is the number of turns of the coil. - \( B \) is the magnetic induction intensity. - \( A \) is the area of the coil. - \( \omega \) is the angular velocity. - \( t \) is the time.
Since timing starts when the coil plane is in the neutral plane, at \( t = 0 \), the coil is perpendicular to the magnetic field lines, and the sine term \( \sin(\omega t) \) becomes 1.

premise: Since timing starts when the coil plane is in the neutral plane, at \( t = 0 \), the coil is perpendicular to the magnetic field lines, and the sine term \( \sin(\omega t) \) becomes 1.
conclusion: The maximum induced EMF, \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{max}} \), can be calculated as \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{max}} = n \cdot B \cdot A \cdot \omega \).
Calculate the Area of the Coil (\( A \)): \( A = l_{AB} \times l_{BC} = 0.2\, \text{m} \times 0.5\, \text{m} = 0.1\, \text{m}^2 \).

conclusion: Calculate the Induced EMF: \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{max}} = n \cdot B \cdot A \cdot \omega \).
